Tendentious Terminology
3. Tendentious Terminology

One lesson to be gleaned from the preceding cases is that
“fideism” is a term that is seldom self-applied. This is
no doubt largely because it has come to function primarily as a term
of abuse as opposed to a genuinely descriptive term. In this respect,
its de facto role is similar to that played by terms like
“relativism” and, perhaps, “anti-realism.”
Such labels generally say at least as much about the philosophical
commitments of those who use them as they do about the positions to
which they are applied.

Popkin argues that the skepticism introduced into theology in the
sixteenth century eventually led to the atheism and irreligious
“free-thinking” of the Enlightenment. After all, Hume says
essentially the same thing as the so-called fideists when he writes
that “[o]ur most holy religion is founded on faith, not
on reason” (140), except that by the eighteenth century this had
been transformed into an implicit – if
not-so-subtle – reproach. Thus, Hume proceeds to add that
since “[m]ere reason is insufficient to convince us of its
veracity…whoever is moved by faith to assent to
[Christianity] is conscious of a continued miracle in his own person
which subverts all the principles of his understanding and gives him a
determination to believe what is most contrary to custom and
experience” (141). The sarcasm here is hard to miss.

One way of understanding the emergence of the category
“fideism” is as a by-product of the development of secular
conceptions of rationality that, while not overtly hostile to
religion, moved God from the premises of thought to its possible
conclusions. On a classical theological account, the Christian
approaches the world coram deo – in God’s
presence. God, on this view, is not the product of inference
from the world but rather its logos, the
hermeneutical key to understanding the world, where the latter is
imagined not as what Charles Taylor calls an “immanent
frame” (542) – a lawlike space that can be understood
fully on its own terms –but as creation. Creation,
conceived coram deo, presupposes a creator, but it is not the
starting point from which one is inferred. This classical Christian
view was gradually displaced by a secular imaginary, in which the
world, while not, as Descartes demonstrated, self-evident, was no
longer viewed as requiring reference to anything beyond itself.
Ostensibly theologically neutral, it thus came to provide a starting
point not simply for atheism, but for a new understanding of natural
theology, in which belief in God could be grounded in probabilistic
arguments from premises not themselves in dispute between believers
and unbelievers.

It is true that the classical arguments for God’s existence
– e.g., Thomas’s “Five Ways” – predate
the development of secular reason, but scholars have argued that their
function changed over time, and that they were not originally intended
as stand-alone proofs that would convince an unbeliever. They operated
within a distinctive theological theater to elucidate it,
rather than providing external foundations for it. John Clayton has
argued that, within pre-modern Judaism and Christianity, theistic
proofs were used within religious communities “to correct
heresy, confirm true belief or simply express awe or wonder”
(92). They were also used apologetically by Christians, but their
target audience was typically other theists, including Muslims.
“[S]ince the Muslims already believed in God, Thomas cannot have
wanted by means of rational argument to convince them that God exists
[…] It would seem more likely that he hoped through rehearsing
such proofs (together with other proofs about God’s nature) to
establish with Muslims a positive basis upon which additionally, more
specifically Christian, arguments could be built” (92–93).
By the seventeenth century this had begun to change. In attempting to
rescue God from the enthusiasm and perceived dogmatism of traditional
religion, deistic thinkers sought to establish a less theologically
ramified, more universal or “natural” religion. Whereas
formerly the proofs had operated emically, within a horizon of shared
theological concerns, “[i]n the new dispensation,” Taylor
argues, “the issues of God’s existence, our relation to
him, what we owe him, and the like, are put by Deism quite outside
this horizon” (294). This shift in the arguments’ role was
accompanied, necessarily, by a corresponding shift in the meaning of
key terms. “The world” which the “disembedded”
proofs take as their point of departure, is no longer the created
order, but the immanent domain of the emerging natural sciences. God
is no longer essential to a proper understanding of the world but a
hypothetical explanation for its existence and order.

These reinterpreted arguments presented new opportunities for
apologetics (such as Paley’s design argument), but they also
exposed belief in God to new forms of criticism (such as those raised
in Hume’s Dialogues Concerning Natural Religion). What
the parties to these disputes had in common was a conception of what
rationality in this realm requires – in particular, premises
neutral with respect to God’s reality. By those lights, earlier
ways of thinking that began from God’s reality, as well
as later ways of thinking that shared this earlier starting point,
appeared irrational and question-begging. “Faith,” which
originally meant something like “trust,” came to refer to
the act of holding beliefs without evidence sufficient to warrant
them. Fideism was thus, paradoxically, the claim that it is
rational to behave irrationally.

Hence, by the time the term “fideism” entered the
philosophical vocabulary, the position it denoted was already highly
suspect. In an Age of Reason, faith-ism is inevitably going
to sound irrational. However, the conception of reason which
the putative fideist is accused of transgressing is almost invariably
one the latter would reject as insufficiently robust. Thus, the
opposition to reason said to characterize fideism is perhaps better
conceived as a rejection of a particular account of
reason – one the so-called fideist regards as overly narrow and
restrictive – or of the applicability to religion of a particular
way of reasoning. To be sure, the thinkers described as
“fideists” have sometimes expressed their objections in
ways that contribute to the impression of irrationalism. Looked at
from this point of view, however, it is the critic of fideism who
fails to appreciate the irony with which the putative fideist uses the
term “reason.” In effect, the putative fideist can
generally more charitably be interpreted as claiming that it can be
rational to refuse to subject certain of one’s beliefs
to what is popularly (though misleadingly, from the point of view of
the putative fideist) called “reason” – reason, so to
speak, in “scare quotes.”

Indeed, from the standpoint of some of the thinkers labled fideistic,
modern natural theology, insofar as it adopts secular premises and
treats God hypothetically, constitutes a theological error. The
twentieth-century Protestant theologian Karl Barth suggested that
Christian natural theology is plagued by an inner contradiction:
“As a ‘Christian’ natural theology, it must really
represent and affirm the standpoint of faith. Its true objective to
which it really wants to lead unbelief is the knowability of the real
God…. But as a ‘natural’ theology, its initial aim is
to disguise this and therefore to pretend to share in the
life-endeavour of natural man” (94). In other words, natural
theology is either insincere – pretending to start from a
standpoint of unbelief – or sinful, since, on Barth’s
Protestant view, unbelief, even in the form of methodological
agnosticism, is not theologically neutral but “active enmity
against God” (94). Natural theology paradoxically requires
abandoning the Christian perspective – at least methodologically
– in a misguided effort to provide God with support God
doesn’t, on a Christian view, need. This Protestant view is, of
course, at odds with the official Catholic view noted earlier.

In philosophical as opposed to theological terms, what the thinkers
labeled “fideists” have tended to find objectionable is
not reason per se, but evidentialism – i.e., the
doctrine (expressed forcefully by Clifford) that beliefs can be
rational only if they are supported by evidence. Since evidentialism
might otherwise seem to give rise to a regress problem, it is
generally conjoined with some version of foundationalism which
purports to delineate a criterion of “proper
basicality” – i.e., a set of conditions under which beliefs
can rationally be held without further evidential support. Whereas
some putative fideists – like Pascal – argue that religious
beliefs can be given non-evidential support, others can be interpreted
as suggesting that such beliefs are themselves properly basic, or (as
Plantinga has argued more recently) that no criterion of proper
basicality that would exclude religious beliefs can itself be shown to
be justified. Their contention in either case is that the believer can
be rationally justified – or at least cannot be shown to be
behaving irrationally – in holding certain beliefs, even
if these beliefs themselves are not supported by evidence. Conceived
of in this way, the putative fideist’s position – though not
uncontroversial – is hardly the brazenly paradoxical doctrine it
might at first appear to be.
